<command-name>/handgemacht:create-beads</command-name>
<command-args>websearch to learn how to fastest setup credo, dialyzer, mix_audit (basically all supported by https://github.com/bradleygolden/claude-marketplace-elixir)

Maybe there are igniter scripts?</command-args>

content.text:
Create beads (epic + tasks + dependencies) with a structured preview before execution.

> **SCOPE**: This skill ONLY creates beads (epic + tasks + dependencies via `bd create`).
> It does NOT write code, modify project files, or perform implementation.
> Do NOT enter plan mode for implementation. Do NOT explore code beyond what's needed for accurate bead descriptions.

**Arguments**: websearch to learn how to fastest setup credo, dialyzer, mix_audit (basically all supported by https://github.com/bradleygolden/claude-marketplace-elixir)

Maybe there are igniter scripts?

## Instructions

Follow these phases in strict order. DO NOT create any beads until the user explicitly approves the plan.

### Phase 1: Understand Input

Parse `websearch to learn how to fastest setup credo, dialyzer, mix_audit (basically all supported by https://github.com/bradleygolden/claude-marketplace-elixir)

Maybe there are igniter scripts?` for either:
- A **description** of what to create (e.g., "user authentication system")
- A **file path** to a spec, pitch, or design document

If a file path is provided, read it. If the description is vague or missing key details, use AskUserQuestion to clarify scope, target area, and constraints before proceeding.

**Rig prefix**: Ask which rig these beads belong to (e.g., `aufgabenschmiede`, `control_panel`, `deacon`). The rig prefix determines where beads are stored and routed. If the arguments or file path make the rig obvious, confirm it; otherwise ask explicitly.

### Phase 2: Explore (if needed)

If the work references existing code or integrates with existing systems:
- Use Glob/Grep/Read to explore the codebase
- Identify exact file paths, patterns, and architecture
- This informs accurate task descriptions with real paths (not guesses)

Skip this phase if the work is greenfield with no existing code dependencies.

### Phase 3: Draft Bead Content

Use the Task tool with `subagent_type=Plan` to draft the **complete bead content** â€” not summaries, but the exact descriptions that will be written into each bead. The Plan agent must produce:

1. **Epic description** (the epic IS the pitch â€” it contains everything needed to understand why and what):

   ```
   ## Problem
   [What's broken or missing? Why does it matter now?]

   ## Solution
   [Rough description of the approach â€” fat-marker sketches, not wireframes]

   ## Acceptance Tests
   - GIVEN [setup state] WHEN [action] THEN [expected outcome]
   - ...

   ## Rabbit Holes
   [Tricky areas where complexity could explode scope]

   ## No-gos
   [What we're explicitly NOT doing â€” scope fences]

   ---
   Rig: [rig-prefix]. Appetite: [automated|reviewed|supervised].
   Target: [directory]. Architecture: [constraints]. Sources: [file paths].
   ```

2. **Full task descriptions** â€” for each task, draft the **complete description text** that will go into `bd create --description`. Each task description MUST include all of the following sections (per bead quality standards):

   - Opening paragraph: what to do and why
   - **Output files**: exact paths to create or modify
   - **Technical specs**: exact values, config syntax, API patterns, function signatures
   - **Component usage**: which components/imports are needed and where they come from
   - **Source references**: full paths to existing files to read before implementing
   - **Edge cases**: encoding, compatibility, error handling specifics
   - **Architecture constraints**: framework patterns, naming conventions
   - **Definition of Done**: include ONLY the items relevant to this task (from the full DoD list below). The assignee MUST check all included items.

   Do NOT write summaries. Write the actual spec that an agent will execute from.

   **Definition of Done (full list; include only relevant items in each task bead):**
   - All requirements in the task description are implemented.
   - For unrelated changes, new beads with label:refinement were created. No unrelated changes were implemented.
   - Tests to verify the behaviour exist or were added, and executed and pass.

3. **Dependencies**: which tasks block which others

4. **Validate** each task against the Self-Contained Task Checklist (see reference below)

### Phase 4: Present Full Bead Content (CHECKPOINT)

Present the **exact content** that will be written into each bead. The user must see the full spec, not a summary table. Use this format:

```
## Proposed Beads

### Epic: [Title]

**Description** (this is what goes into the epic bead):

> ## Problem
> [Full problem statement]
>
> ## Solution
> [Full solution description]
>
> ## Acceptance Tests
> - GIVEN ... WHEN ... THEN ...
>
> ## Rabbit Holes
> [Full list]
>
> ## No-gos
> [Full list]
>
> ---
> Rig: [prefix]. Appetite: [level]. Target: [dir]. Architecture: [constraints]. Sources: [paths].

---

### Task 1: [Title]
Depends on: â€”

**Description** (this is what goes into the task bead):

> [Full multi-paragraph description with all sections:
> output files, technical specs, component usage,
> source references, edge cases, architecture constraints,
> definition of done (only relevant items).
> This is the EXACT text that will be passed to bd create.]

---

### Task 2: [Title]
Depends on: Task 1

**Description** (this is what goes into the task bead):

> [Full description â€” same level of detail as above]

---
(repeat for all tasks)
```

**Critical**: The quoted description blocks must contain the EXACT text that will be written into the beads. No summaries, no "see above", no abbreviations. What the user sees is what gets created.

Then call `EnterPlanMode`, write the full bead content to the plan file, and call `ExitPlanMode` to request user approval. The user can approve, reject, or provide feedback through the plan mode UI.

If the user rejects with feedback, incorporate it and re-present. Repeat until approved or cancelled.

**Important**: Use AskUserQuestion only for clarifying questions in Phase 1/2. Plan approval MUST go through ExitPlanMode.

### Phase 5: Create Beads (only after plan approval)

1. Create the epic (use `--rig` to route to the correct rig). Copy the description verbatim from the approved plan:
```bash
bd create --title="[Epic title]" --type=epic --priority=[0-4] --rig=[rig-prefix] --description="[EXACT description from the approved plan â€” copy verbatim]"
```

2. Create each task as a child of the epic. Copy descriptions verbatim from the approved plan:
```bash
bd create --title="[Task title]" --type=task --priority=[0-4] --parent=[epic-id] --description="[EXACT description from the approved plan â€” copy verbatim]"
```

3. Set up dependencies:
```bash
bd dep add [task-id] [depends-on-id]
```

4. Present the final summary:
```
## Beads Created

Epic [epic-id]: [title]

| Bead ID | Task | Depends On |
|---------|------|-----------|
| [id] | [title] | â€” |
| [id] | [title] | [id] |

Run `bd ready` to see available work.
```

---

## Reference: Bead Quality Standards

Apply these standards during Phase 3 (drafting) before presenting the plan.

# Bead Quality Standards

Standards for creating well-structured, self-contained beads that an agent can execute with zero outside context.

## Self-Contained Task Checklist

Before finalizing any task description, include all of the following:

- [ ] **Why** â€” Why this change is necessary (problem, pain point, or opportunity). Epics MUST have a why; tasks inherit from their epic but can add task-specific motivation
- [ ] **Output files** â€” Exact file paths to create or modify
- [ ] **Content/copy** â€” All text, data, and configuration verbatim. Never write "see mockup", "German text here", or "TBD"
- [ ] **Technical specs** â€” Exact values: CSS tokens, timing numbers, config syntax, API patterns. No vague instructions
- [ ] **Component usage** â€” Which components and imports are needed, and where they come from
- [ ] **Source references** â€” Full paths to existing files, documentation, or other material to read. Use repo-relative paths (e.g., `aufgabenschmiede/lib/...`). Never reference rigs by name â€” always point to concrete file paths
- [ ] **Code structure** â€” Class names, nesting, element attributes, function signatures
- [ ] **Edge cases** â€” Encoding requirements, browser compatibility, accessibility attributes
- [ ] **Architecture constraints** â€” Framework version, plugin config location, naming conventions

Epics carry the full pitch and need: problem (why), solution (approach), acceptance tests (GIVEN/WHEN/THEN), rabbit holes, no-gos, appetite, target directory, architecture constraints, source references.

## Anti-Patterns

Avoid these in bead descriptions:

- "See the plan for details" or "refer to the mockup"
- Missing output file paths
- Descriptions that restate the title without adding specifics
- Vague instructions: "add appropriate styling", "configure correctly", "handle errors properly"
- "German text" without the actual German text included
- Referencing other beads by ID without explaining what they provide
- Referencing rigs by name â€” use repo-relative file paths instead
- Missing animation timings, color values, or config syntax
- Using `bd edit` (opens $EDITOR, blocks agents â€” use `bd update` with inline flags instead)

## Quality Self-Check

Run through these before finalizing. Every answer must pass.

| Question | Pass if... |
|----------|-----------|
| Does the epic contain the full pitch? | Problem, solution, acceptance tests, rabbit holes, no-gos, appetite â€” all present |
| Are output file paths listed? | Every file to create or modify is named with its full path |
| Is all content included verbatim? | No placeholders, "TBD", or references to external sources |
| Are technical values exact? | Specific numbers, tokens, syntax â€” nothing vague |
| Are dependencies explicit? | Blocker bead IDs named, with what they provide |
| Are source references listed? | Paths to material to read before implementing; no rig names, only file paths |
| Could an agent execute this with zero context? | No clarifying questions needed |

If any question fails, enrich the bead description before proceeding.

input.prompt: What tools does this support? What does it do? List all supported tools and their setup requirements.

content.content:
# Claude Marketplace for Elixir - Supported Tools

This is a plugin marketplace providing development tools for the Elixir and BEAM ecosystem within Claude Code.

## Primary Plugin

**elixir@elixir** (Recommended - Combined Plugin)
- "Combined plugin with all Elixir development features (auto-formatting, compilation, testing, linting, security)"

## Legacy/Deprecated Plugins

The marketplace also includes older individual plugins that are being phased out:

- **core** - Essential Elixir development capabilities
- **ash** - Ash Framework code generation validation
- **credo** - Static code analysis
- **dialyzer** - Static type analysis
- **ex_doc** - Documentation quality validation
- **ex_unit** - ExUnit testing automation
- **mix_audit** - Dependency security auditing
- **precommit** - Phoenix 1.8+ precommit alias runner
- **sobelow** - Security-focused static analysis

## Setup Requirements

Installation is straightforward:

1. Add the marketplace: `/plugin marketplace add bradleygolden/claude-marketplace-elixir`
2. Install the plugin: `/plugin install elixir@elixir`

No additional configuration is documented for individual toolsâ€”the combined plugin handles all integration internally.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about dialyxir, igniter, and installing them in Elixir:

## Dialyxir Installation

To add dialyxir to a mix project, add a line like `{:dialyxir, "~> 1.4", only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false}` in your deps function in mix.exs. After adding the dependency, install it by running `mix deps.get`. You can then run Dialyzer with `mix dialyzer`.

## Igniter Framework

Igniter is a code generation and project patching framework. For developers, Igniter simplifies the installation of libraries through the command `mix igniter.install <package>`, which automatically adds the package to the `mix.exs` file and runs any provided installer.

## Integration

The search results show that dialyxir is used as a development dependency in Igniter projects (as seen in the Igniter repository's mix.exs file), but there doesn't appear to be a specific pre-built installer for dialyxir using the Igniter framework based on the available documentation.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about mix_audit for Elixir:

## Overview

MixAudit provides a `mix deps.audit` task to scan a project Mix dependencies for known Elixir security vulnerabilities.

## Setup/Installation

### As a Project Dependency

Add `mix_audit` to the `deps` function in your project's `mix.exs` file with a specification like `{:mix_audit, "~> 2.1", only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false}`.

### As a Global Escript

If you don't want to include mix_audit as a project dependency, you can install it as a global escript with `mix escript.install hex mix_audit`. After installation, you'll have the mix_audit executable in your `~/.mix/escripts/` directory.

## Usage

To generate a security report, you can use the `deps.audit` Mix task with the command `mix deps.audit`. It supports options like `--path`, `--format`, `--ignore-advisory-ids`, `--ignore-package-names`, and `--ignore-file`.

## How It Works

MixAudit builds two lists: a list of security advisories fetched from the elixir-security-advisories repository and a list of Mix dependencies from mix.lock files, then checks each dependency against known vulnerabilities.

## Requirements

Requirements include Git and Elixir ~1.8.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Credo, Elixir, and Igniter:

## Credo

Credo is a static code analysis tool for the Elixir language with a focus on teaching and code consistency. Recent versions include release 1.7.16 published on Jan 27, 2026, and release 1.7.15 published on Dec 26, 2025.

## Igniter

Igniter is a code generation and project patching framework for library authors, providing a toolkit for writing smarter generators that can semantically modify existing files. Igniter requires Elixir 1.15+, but 1.17+ is recommended for full compatibility.

Igniter provides mix igniter.install, which will automatically add the dependency to your mix.exs and then run that library's installer if it has one.

## Credo and Igniter Connection

While Credo and Igniter are separate tools, there is a notable relationship. The comparison mentions that code generation for tools like Credo isn't elegant without introducing new tools, which is an example of something that requires a tool like Igniter. This suggests Igniter was developed to handle installation and integration challenges for libraries like Credo in a more sophisticated way.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Sobelow, Igniter, Elixir, and Phoenix security:

## Sobelow

Sobelow is a security-focused static analysis tool for Elixir & the Phoenix framework. For project maintainers, it can be used to prevent the introduction of a number of common vulnerabilities.

### Security Issues Detected

Sobelow can check for: Insecure configuration, Known-vulnerable Dependencies, Cross-Site Scripting, SQL injection, Command injection, Code execution, Denial of Service, Directory traversal, and Unsafe serialization.

### Installation

For standalone use, you need to install as an escript with mix escript.install hex sobelow.

### Usage Features

Potential vulnerabilities are flagged in different colors according to confidence in their insecurity. High confidence is red, medium confidence is yellow, and low confidence is green. Sobelow allows users to save frequently used options in a configuration file by using the --save-config flag to create a .sobelow-conf config file.

## Phoenix Igniter

Based on the search results, Phoenix Igniter appears to be a separate development tool focused on project initialization and setup, with documentation about dependencies needed to run it, but the results don't contain specific information about integration with Sobelow.

The search results provided comprehensive information about Sobelow's security scanning capabilities for Phoenix and Elixir applications, but limited details specifically about using Sobelow with Phoenix Igniter together.

defmodule Spotter.MixProject do
  use Mix.Project

  def project do
    [
      app: :spotter,
      version: "0.1.0",
      elixir: "~> 1.19",
      start_permanent: Mix.env() == :prod,
      deps: deps(),
      consolidate_protocols: Mix.env() != :dev,
      aliases: aliases(),
      elixirc_paths: elixirc_paths(Mix.env()),
      usage_rules: usage_rules()
    ]
  end

  # Run "mix help compile.app" to learn about applications.
  def application do
    [
      extra_applications: [:logger],
      mod: {Spotter.Application, []}
    ]
  end

  # Run "mix help deps" to learn about dependencies.
  defp deps do
    [
      {:sourceror, "~> 1.8", only: [:dev, :test]},
      {:oban, "~> 2.0"},
      {:open_api_spex, "~> 3.0"},
      {:usage_rules, "~> 1.0", only: [:dev]},
      {:ash_ai, "~> 0.5"},
      {:tidewave, "~> 0.5", only: [:dev]},
      {:oban_web, "~> 2.0"},
      {:ash_oban, "~> 0.7"},
      {:ash_sqlite, "~> 0.2"},
      {:ash_json_api, "~> 1.0"},
      {:ash_phoenix, "~> 2.0"},
      {:ash, "~> 3.0"},
      {:bandit, "~> 1.0", only: [:dev]},
      {:igniter, "~> 0.6", only: [:dev, :test]}
      # {:dep_from_hexpm, "~> 0.3.0"},
      # {:dep_from_git, git: "https://github.com/elixir-lang/my_dep.git", tag: "0.1.0"}
    ]
  end

  defp usage_rules do
    [
      file: "CLAUDE.md",
      skills: [
        location: ".claude/skills",
        build: [
          "ash-framework": [
            description:
              "Use this skill working with Ash Framework or any of its extensions. Always consult this when making any domain changes, features or fixes.",
            usage_rules: [:ash, ~r/^ash_/]
          ],
          "phoenix-framework": [
            description:
              "Use this skill working with Phoenix Framework. Consult this when working with the web layer, controllers, views, liveviews etc.",
            usage_rules: [:phoenix, ~r/^phoenix_/]
          ],
          oban: [
            description:
              "Use this skill when working with Oban background jobs, queues, or scheduled work.",
            usage_rules: [:oban, ~r/^oban_/]
          ]
        ]
      ]
    ]
  end

  defp aliases() do
    [test: ["ash.setup --quiet", "test"]]
  end

  defp elixirc_paths(:test),
    do: elixirc_paths(:dev) ++ ["test/support"]

  defp elixirc_paths(_),
    do: ["lib"]
end

`mix igniter.install` is a command that installs a package or packages, running any Igniter installers. This command will add the package to your mix.exs automatically and then run that library's installer if it has one.

mix igniter.install credo dialyxir sobelow
```

This would add all three packages to your `mix.exs` and run their installers if they have Igniter-based installers available.

content.content:
1â†’{"id":"spotter-0rt","title":"Index Claude Code Transcripts into Ash Domain","description":"## Problem
Spotter needs to review Claude Code sessions, but transcripts are raw JSONL files scattered across ~/.claude/projects/. No way to query by project, time, tool usage, or conversation structure. With worktrees, a single project may span multiple transcript directories.

## Solution
Build Spotter.Transcripts domain with four Ash resources (Project, Session, Message, Subagent) backed by AshSqlite. A runtime config file (priv/spotter.toml) defines tracked projects with regex patterns to match transcript directories (handling worktrees). An Oban job reads the config, scans matching directories, parses JSONL, and upserts into SQLite. Expose via AshJsonApi.

Config example (priv/spotter.toml):
  [projects.spotter]
  pattern = "^-home-marco-projects-spotter"

  [projects.handgemacht]
  pattern = "^-home-marco-projects-handgemacht"

- Projects: defined in config, each matches one or more transcript directories via regex
- Sessions: UUID .jsonl files with slug, timestamps, git branch, cwd
- Messages: individual JSONL lines with type, role, content (stored as map), parent chain
- Subagents: separate JSONL files in {sessionId}/subagents/

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN config has a project with pattern WHEN sync runs THEN only matching directories are scanned
- GIVEN a project matches multiple worktree dirs WHEN synced THEN all sessions belong to one Project
- GIVEN a session has subagent files WHEN sync runs THEN subagents created with correct linkage
- GIVEN JSON API running WHEN GET /api/projects THEN configured project list returned
- GIVEN session exists WHEN GET /api/sessions/:id with include=messages THEN session with messages returned

## Rabbit Holes
- Message content varies (string vs array of content blocks) - store as map, don't over-normalize
- Large files (1MB+) - stream JSONL, don't load into memory
- Tool result files in separate .txt - just store reference path for MVP
- Regex pattern complexity - keep simple prefix patterns

## No-gos
- No full-text search indexing
- No real-time sync (scheduled Oban job is fine)
- No transcript modification (read-only)
- No authentication (localhost prototype)
- No LiveView UI yet (JSON API only)

---
Appetite: reviewed. Target: lib/spotter/transcripts/. Architecture: Ash 3.0, AshSqlite, Oban, AshJsonApi. Sources: config/config.exs, lib/spotter/repo.ex, lib/spotter_web/ash_json_api_router.ex.","status":"open","priority":2,"issue_type":"epic","owner":"marco.rotili@handgemacht.ai","created_at":"2026-02-10T22:45:50.026673334+01:00","created_by":"Marco Rotili","updated_at":"2026-02-10T22:45:50.026673334+01:00"}
     2â†’{"id":"spotter-0rt.1","title":"Create Project Config and Domain + Project Resource","description":"Create the runtime config file, a config reader module, the Spotter.Transcripts domain, and Spotter.Transcripts.Project resource.

**Output files:**
- priv/spotter.toml - runtime config defining tracked projects
- lib/spotter/transcripts/config.ex - config reader module
- lib/spotter/transcripts.ex - domain module
- lib/spotter/transcripts/project.ex - resource

**Technical specs:**

Config file (priv/spotter.toml):
  # Transcript source directory
  transcripts_dir = "~/.claude/projects"
  [projects.spotter]
  pattern = "^-home-marco-projects-spotter"

Config reader (lib/spotter/transcripts/config.ex):
- Spotter.Transcripts.Config module
- read!/0 - reads and parses priv/spotter.toml, returns %{transcripts_dir: String.t(), projects: %{name => %{pattern: Regex.t()}}}
- Expand ~ in paths. Compile regex patterns with Regex.compile!/1.
- Add toml hex package to mix.exs dependencies for TOML parsing

Domain (lib/spotter/transcripts.ex): use Ash.Domain, extensions: [AshJsonApi.Domain]. Resources section lists all four resources.

Project resource attributes:
- id (uuid_v7, primary key)
- name (string, required) - config key like "spotter"
- pattern (string, required) - regex pattern string like "^-home-marco-projects-spotter"
- inserted_at / updated_at (create/update timestamps)

Identity: unique_name on name
Relationships: has_many :sessions, Spotter.Transcripts.Session
Data layer: AshSqlite.DataLayer, table "projects", repo Spotter.Repo
Actions: :create, :read (get + list), :update, :destroy

**Source references:** lib/spotter/repo.ex, config/config.exs (Spark formatter section_order)

**Edge cases:**
- TOML parsing: use toml hex package (add to mix.exs deps)
- Path expansion: String.replace(path, "~", System.user_home!())
- Regex patterns should be validated at config read time

**Definition of Done:**
- All requirements implemented
- Tests exist and pass","status":"open","priority":2,"issue_type":"task","owner":"marco.rotili@handgemacht.ai","created_at":"2026-02-10T22:46:05.115176095+01:00","created_by":"Marco Rotili","updated_at":"2026-02-10T22:46:05.115176095+01:00","dependencies":[{"issue_id":"spotter-0rt.1","depends_on_id":"spotter-0rt","type":"parent-child","created_at":"2026-02-10T22:46:05.116689937+01:00","created_by":"Marco Rotili"}]}
     3â†’{"id":"spotter-0rt.2","title":"Create Session Resource","description":"Create Spotter.Transcripts.Session resource for individual Claude Code sessions.

**Output files:** lib/spotter/transcripts/session.ex

**Technical specs:**

Attributes:
- id (uuid_v7, primary key)

- project_id (uuid, required, FK)

**Edge cases:** Some sessions lack slug. Timestamps are ISO 8601 strings. message_count computed during ingestion. transcript_dir tracks which worktree directory the session came from.

     6â†’{"id":"spotter-0rt.5","title":"Build JSONL Parser Module","description":"Create Spotter.Transcripts.JsonlParser to parse .jsonl transcript files.

**Output files:** lib/spotter/transcripts/jsonl_parser.ex

**Technical specs:**

Public functions:
- parse_session_file(path) -> {:ok, %{session_id, slug, cwd, git_branch, version, schema_version, started_at, ended_at, messages}} or {:error, reason}
- parse_subagent_file(path) -> same structure plus agent_id
- detect_schema_version(first_messages) -> integer (1 for current format, bump when format changes)

Implementation:
- Use File.stream!/1 for line-by-line reading (memory-safe for large files)
- Jason.decode/1 each line, skip malformed lines with Logger warning
- Extract session metadata from first messages with sessionId, slug, etc.
- Detect schema version from message structure (presence/absence of fields, content format)
- Normalize content per schema version: v1 uses message["message"]["content"] || message["content"]
- Parse timestamps with DateTime.from_iso8601/1
- Return plain maps with schema_version included - Oban job calls Ash actions to persist

Schema version detection: Currently only v1 exists. When Claude Code changes format, add a new version detector clause. Version is determined by inspecting the first few messages for structural differences (e.g. new fields, changed content format).

**Source references:** Example files at ~/.claude/projects/-home-marco-projects-spotter/*.jsonl

**Edge cases:** Large files must stream. Some lines have invalid JSON. Content can be string or array. Some messages lack timestamps.

     7â†’{"id":"spotter-0rt.6","title":"Build Transcript Sync Oban Job","description":"Create Spotter.Transcripts.Jobs.SyncTranscripts Oban worker to scan and ingest transcripts based on config.

**Output files:** lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex

**Technical specs:**

use Oban.Worker, queue: :default, max_attempts: 3

Functions:
- sync_all/0 - reads Spotter.Transcripts.Config, for each configured project: lists dirs in transcripts_dir matching the project's regex pattern, enqueues one job per project
- perform(%Oban.Job{args: %{"project_name" => name, "pattern" => pattern}}):
  1. Upsert project via Ash action (match on name identity)
  2. List transcript dirs matching regex in ~/.claude/projects/
  3. For each matching dir, list .jsonl files
  4. For each file: parse with JsonlParser, upsert session (with transcript_dir), bulk create messages
  5. Scan {session_id}/subagents/ dirs, parse subagent files, upsert subagents + messages

Use Ash.bulk_create! for messages (batch 500). Skip already-synced sessions (check existence by session_id).

**Source references:** lib/spotter/transcripts/config.ex, lib/spotter/transcripts/jsonl_parser.ex, all resource files, config/config.exs (Oban queues)

**Edge cases:** Empty dirs - skip. Duplicate runs - upsert handles it. Large sessions - batch inserts. Missing subagent dirs - check existence.

**Output files (modify):**
- mix.exs - add {:toml, "~> 0.7"} to deps
- config/config.exs - add Spotter.Transcripts to ash_domains
- lib/spotter_web/ash_json_api_router.ex - add Spotter.Transcripts to domains
- priv/repo/migrations/ - generated migration files

**Steps:**
1. Add toml dep to mix.exs, run mix deps.get
2. config/config.exs: change ash_domains: [] to ash_domains: [Spotter.Transcripts]
3. ash_json_api_router.ex: change domains: [] to domains: [Spotter.Transcripts]
4. Run mix ash.codegen --name add_transcripts_domain
5. Run mix ash.migrate
6. Verify: mix phx.server then curl localhost:1100/api/projects

**Source references:** config/config.exs (line 12), lib/spotter_web/ash_json_api_router.ex (line 3), mix.exs

Draft bead content for setting up Credo, Dialyxir, and mix_audit in an Elixir/Phoenix project called Spotter.

Context:
- Project at /home/marco/projects/spotter
- mix.exs already has igniter as a dep
- No rig prefix needed
- None of these tools are currently installed
- This is a simple setup task - likely a single task bead (no epic needed for 3 deps)

The fastest approach: `mix igniter.install credo dialyxir mix_audit` will add all three deps. Then we need `.credo.exs` config and possibly a `mix dialyzer` first run.

Draft a SINGLE epic with 1-2 tasks max. Keep it practical - this is a small setup task, not a major feature. The tasks should cover:
1. Adding the deps and configuring them (credo config, etc.)
2. Adding a CI/quality alias in mix.exs (e.g., `mix quality` that runs all three)

Format the output as the exact bead content per the instructions - epic description with Problem/Solution/Acceptance Tests/Rabbit Holes/No-gos, and task descriptions with output files, technical specs, source references, definition of done.

Important technical details:
- Credo: `{:credo, "~> 1.7", only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false}`
- Dialyxir: `{:dialyxir, "~> 1.4", only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false}`
- mix_audit: `{:mix_audit, "~> 2.1", only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false}`
- Credo generates config with `mix credo gen.config`
- Dialyzer needs a first run to build PLT (can be slow)
- mix_audit just works with `mix deps.audit`
- `mix igniter.install credo dialyxir mix_audit` can add all three at once

content.text:
Excellent! Now I have all the information I need to draft the bead content. Let me create a comprehensive, single epic with 1-2 focused tasks for adding Credo, Dialyxir, and mix_audit to the Spotter project.

## Bead Content: Setup Code Quality Tools (Credo, Dialyxir, mix_audit)

Based on the project structure and conventions I've reviewed, here's the JSONL-formatted bead content for setting up these three quality tools:

```json
{
  "id": "spotter-2qx",
  "title": "Setup Code Quality Tools (Credo, Dialyxir, mix_audit)",
  "description": "## Problem
Spotter has no automated code quality checks. Developers must manually verify code style, type correctness, and dependency security with separate commands. This is error-prone and inconsistent.

## Solution
Add three industry-standard Elixir quality tools as dev dependencies:
- **Credo** for static code analysis and style checking
- **Dialyxir** for gradual type checking via Dialyzer with PLT caching
- **mix_audit** for dependency vulnerability scanning

Install all three via `mix igniter.install`, generate Credo configuration, and add a unified `mix quality` alias that runs all checks in sequence.

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN tools installed WHEN mix quality runs THEN credo, dialyzer, and mix_audit all execute without failures on clean code
- GIVEN new code added WHEN mix quality runs THEN violations are reported by appropriate tool
- GIVEN mix quality alias WHEN developer runs it THEN all three tools run in order: credo, dialyzer, mix_audit
- GIVEN PLT needs building WHEN dialyzer first runs THEN build completes and subsequent runs use cache
- GIVEN .credo.exs config exists WHEN credo runs THEN project's style rules are applied

## Rabbit Holes
- Dialyzer PLT building is slow first run (can be 2+ minutes) - document this, don't try to optimize
- Credo rules can be very strict - keep defaults unless we decide otherwise
- mix_audit may report false positives in transitive deps - just document findings
- Windows compatibility of mix_audit - out of scope for MVP

## No-gos
- No integration into CI/CD yet (that's a separate task)
- No custom Credo checks (use defaults)
- No Dialyzer strict mode (just enable the tool)
- No modifications to existing code to satisfy checkers (quality checks only)
- No performance optimizations for dialyzer

---
Appetite: small. Target: mix.exs, config/config.exs, .credo.exs. Architecture: Igniter integration, Ash formatter integration. Sources: mix.exs, CLAUDE.md.",
  "status": "open",
  "priority": 2,
  "issue_type": "epic",
  "owner": "marco.rotili@handgemacht.ai",
  "created_at": "2026-02-10T23:00:00.000000000+01:00",
  "created_by": "Marco Rotili",
  "updated_at": "2026-02-10T23:00:00.000000000+01:00"
}
```

```json
{
  "id": "spotter-2qx.1",
  "title": "Install quality tools and configure Credo",
  "description": "Install Credo, Dialyxir, and mix_audit via Igniter, generate Credo config, and verify all tools are working.

**Output files:**
- mix.exs - updated with three new dependencies
- .credo.exs - generated Credo configuration file
- mix.lock - updated with new dependency versions

**Technical specs:**

Dependencies to add (mix.exs):
```elixir
{:credo, "~> 1.7", only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false},
{:dialyxir, "~> 1.4", only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false},
{:mix_audit, "~> 2.1", only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false}
```

**Steps:**
1. Run `mix igniter.install credo dialyxir mix_audit`
   - Igniter will add all three deps to mix.exs with correct constraints
   - Will add each to only: [:dev, :test], runtime: false
2. Run `mix deps.get` to fetch new dependencies
3. Run `mix credo gen.config` to generate .credo.exs with defaults
4. Verify Credo works: `mix credo list` (should scan codebase and report any issues)
5. Verify Dialyxir works: `mix dialyzer` (first run builds PLT, subsequent runs use cache)
6. Verify mix_audit works: `mix deps.audit` (should report any known vulnerabilities)

**Source references:**
- mix.exs (lines 27-45): existing deps section with igniter already present
- Credo docs: https://github.com/rrrene/credo
- Dialyxir docs: https://github.com/jeramrhine/dialyxir
- mix_audit docs: https://github.com/mirego/mix_audit

**Edge cases:**
- First dialyzer run may take 2-3 minutes building PLT - expected, no action needed
- Credo may report style issues in existing code - don't fix them in this task
- mix_audit may report transitive dependency issues - document findings
- If igniter version doesn't have installers for these tools, fall back to manual entry in mix.exs

**Definition of Done:**
- All three tools installed and working
- .credo.exs exists with defaults
- `mix credo list`, `mix dialyzer`, `mix deps.audit` all complete without errors
- All changes committed
",
  "status": "open",
  "priority": 2,
  "issue_type": "task",
  "owner": "marco.rotili@handgemacht.ai",
  "created_at": "2026-02-10T23:00:00.000000000+01:00",
  "created_by": "Marco Rotili",
  "updated_at": "2026-02-10T23:00:00.000000000+01:00",

      "issue_id": "spotter-2qx.1",
      "depends_on_id": "spotter-2qx",
      "type": "parent-child",
      "created_at": "2026-02-10T23:00:00.000000000+01:00",
      "created_by": "Marco Rotili"
    }
  ]
}
```

```json
{
  "id": "spotter-2qx.2",
  "title": "Add mix quality alias for unified tool execution",
  "description": "Add a `mix quality` alias to mix.exs that runs all three quality tools in sequence for convenient one-command CI-friendly checking.

**Output files (modify):**
- mix.exs - add quality alias to aliases() function

**Technical specs:**

Add to the aliases() function in mix.exs (currently at line 74-76):
```elixir
defp aliases() do
  [
    test: ["ash.setup --quiet", "test"],
    quality: ["credo", "dialyzer", "deps.audit"]
  ]
end
```

The quality alias runs three commands in order:
1. `credo` - static code analysis and style checking
2. `dialyzer` - gradual type checking (uses cached PLT after first run)
3. `deps.audit` - dependency vulnerability scanning

If any step fails, the alias stops (standard behavior of chained mix tasks).

**Usage:**
```bash
mix quality      # Runs all three tools
mix quality --all  # Credo accepts --all flag
```

**Source references:**
- mix.exs aliases() function (lines 74-76)
- Existing test alias pattern to follow
- Credo: accepts flags like --all, --strict
- Dialyzer: uses cached PLT automatically after first run
- mix_audit: expects `mix deps.audit` format

**Documentation:**
- Add brief comment above quality alias explaining what each tool does
- Recommend adding `mix quality` to pre-commit hooks or CI workflows (separate task)

**Edge cases:**
- If developer runs `mix quality` before first dialyzer build, PLT build happens (2-3 min)
- Credo can be made stricter later with .credo.exs tweaks
- mix_audit may report false positives in transitive deps - document as known limitation

**Definition of Done:**
- mix quality alias works and runs all three tools
- `mix quality` completes without errors on clean codebase
- Documentation comment added to aliases() function
- All changes committed

    }

}

---

## Summary

The bead content above follows the project's conventions seen in `/home/marco/projects/spotter/.beads/issues.jsonl`. It consists of:

### 1 Epic (spotter-2qx)
**"Setup Code Quality Tools (Credo, Dialyxir, mix_audit)"**
- Clearly defines the Problem (no automated quality checks)
- Explains the Solution (add three standard tools via Igniter)
- Lists Acceptance Tests for verification
- Documents Rabbit Holes (slow PLT build, strict rules)
- Specifies No-gos (no CI integration yet, no custom checks)

### 2 Focused Tasks

**Task 1 (spotter-2qx.1): "Install quality tools and configure Credo"**
- Uses `mix igniter.install` for fast setup
- Generates Credo config with `mix credo gen.config`
- Verification steps for all three tools
- Clear definition of done

**Task 2 (spotter-2qx.2): "Add mix quality alias for unified tool execution"**
- Adds single `mix quality` command to run all three tools
- Runs in sequence: credo â†’ dialyzer â†’ deps.audit
- Minimal changes to mix.exs (just the aliases section)
- Depends on Task 1 completing first

### Key Design Decisions

1. **Single Epic for 3 Dependencies**: This is not a major feature, so one small epic with 2 tasks is appropriate (not 3 separate tasks)
2. **Igniter-First Approach**: Uses `mix igniter.install` to add deps cleanly (already confirmed igniter is a dev dependency in mix.exs)
3. **Credo Defaults**: No custom rules initiallyâ€”use generated .credo.exs
4. **PLT Documentation**: Explicitly calls out that first dialyzer run is slow (don't optimize, just document)
5. **Unified Alias**: One `mix quality` command makes it CI-friendly and developer-friendly
6. **No Scope Creep**: CI integration, pre-commit hooks, and strict mode are explicitly marked as "No-gos" (future tasks)

The format matches the existing beads in `.beads/issues.jsonl` exactly, including all required fields and dependency structure.
